questions.question: Which of the following is included in other comprehensive income?

options.B: Unrealized gains on AFS debt securities
options.C: Realized gains on sale of equipment

questions.explanation: OCI includes: unrealized G/L on AFS debt securities, foreign currency translation adjustments, certain pension adjustments, and cash flow hedge G/L. Trading securities go to net income.
questions.tip: OCI: AFS, pensions, hedges, foreign translation.

questions.question: Which pension-related item is reported in OCI?

options.B: Interest cost
options.C: Prior service cost arising in the current period

questions.explanation: Prior service cost from plan amendments and actuarial gains/losses are initially recognized in OCI, then amortized to pension expense. Service cost, interest cost, and expected return are in net income.
questions.tip: Pension OCI: prior service cost and gains/losses (before amortization).

questions.question: Comprehensive income may be presented in:

options.B: Only two separate statements
options.C: Either a single continuous statement or two consecutive statements
options.D: Only within the notes to the financial statements

questions.explanation: Entities can present comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement (income statement + OCI) or in two separate but consecutive statements.
questions.tip: Comprehensive income: one statement or two consecutive statements.

questions.question: Net income is $500,000. OCI items: AFS unrealized gain $20,000, foreign translation loss $15,000, pension actuarial loss $10,000. What is total comprehensive income?
questions.tip: Total comprehensive income = Net income + OCI.

questions.question: When AFS securities are sold, the reclassification adjustment:

options.A: Increases OCI and decreases net income
options.B: Moves the realized gain from AOCI to net income, reducing OCI in the period
options.C: Has no effect on comprehensive income
options.D: Increases both OCI and net income

questions.explanation: When realized, the unrealized gain is removed from AOCI (reducing OCI) and recognized in net income. Total comprehensive income is unaffected (net effect of NI increase and OCI decrease cancel out).
questions.tip: Reclassification: removes from AOCI, recognizes in NI; CI unchanged.

questions.question: Accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI) is reported:

options.B: As an asset
options.C: As a component of stockholders' equity

questions.explanation: AOCI is a component of stockholders' equity, presented separately from retained earnings and additional paid-in capital.
questions.tip: AOCI = stockholders' equity component.

questions.question: A company repurchases 1,000 shares of its $10 par stock for $35 per share. Using the cost method, what is the debit to treasury stock?
questions.explanation: Cost method: Dr. Treasury Stock at cost = 1,000 × $35 = $35,000. Par value is irrelevant under cost method.
questions.tip: Cost method treasury stock = shares × purchase price.

questions.question: Treasury stock (cost $35/share) is reissued for $40/share (500 shares). What is credited to APIC?
questions.explanation: Reissuance above cost: Dr. Cash $20,000 (500 × $40), Cr. Treasury Stock $17,500 (500 × $35), Cr. APIC $2,500 (excess).
questions.tip: Treasury reissued above cost: excess goes to APIC.

questions.question: Treasury stock (cost $35/share) is reissued for $28/share (200 shares). No APIC from prior treasury transactions exists. What account is debited for the $7 difference per share?

options.B: Retained earnings (if no APIC-treasury stock available)
options.C: Loss on reissuance of treasury stock

questions.explanation: Reissued below cost: the difference reduces APIC-Treasury Stock first. If none exists, retained earnings is debited. Never recognize a loss.
questions.tip: Treasury below cost: reduce APIC-Treasury first, then retained earnings.

questions.question: A company with 100,000 shares ($5 par, $30 FV) declares a 10% stock dividend. What amount is transferred from retained earnings?
questions.explanation: Small dividend (<20-25%): use FV. Shares = 100,000 × 10% = 10,000. RE reduction = 10,000 × $30 = $300,000.
questions.tip: Small stock dividend (<20-25%): record at fair value.

questions.question: A company with 100,000 shares ($5 par, $30 FV) declares a 30% stock dividend. What amount is transferred from retained earnings?
questions.explanation: Large dividend (>20-25%): use par value. Shares = 100,000 × 30% = 30,000. RE reduction = 30,000 × $5 = $150,000.
questions.tip: Large stock dividend (>20-25%): record at par value.

questions.question: A 2-for-1 stock split results in:

options.A: Transfer from retained earnings to common stock
options.B: Increase in total stockholders' equity
options.C: Decrease in par value per share with no change in total equity

questions.explanation: A stock split increases shares outstanding and proportionately decreases par value per share. No journal entry; total equity unchanged.
questions.tip: Stock split: memo entry only; par per share decreases.

questions.question: A company has 10,000 shares of 6%, $100 par cumulative preferred stock. Dividends were not paid for 2 years. This year, $180,000 is declared. What do common shareholders receive?
questions.explanation: Annual preferred dividend = 10,000 × $100 × 6% = $60,000. Arrears = 2 × $60,000 = $120,000. Current year = $60,000. Total owed = $180,000. Common receives $180,000 - $180,000 = $0.
questions.tip: Cumulative preferred: pay arrears + current before common.

questions.question: Fully participating preferred stock means:

options.B: Preferred shares in dividends beyond the stated rate on the same basis as common
options.C: Preferred stock is convertible
options.D: Preferred receives dividends only if declared

questions.explanation: Fully participating preferred means after both preferred and common receive their stated dividends, any excess is shared proportionately based on relative par/stated values.
questions.tip: Participating: shares excess dividends with common.

questions.question: Which directly affects retained earnings?

options.B: Foreign currency translation adjustments
options.C: Cash dividends declared
options.D: Issuance of common stock at a premium

questions.explanation: Dividends declared reduce retained earnings. Unrealized AFS gains and translation adjustments go to AOCI. Stock issuance goes to common stock and APIC.
questions.tip: RE = NI - Dividends ± Prior period adjustments.

questions.question: Appropriated retained earnings represent:

options.A: Cash set aside for future use
options.B: A restriction on dividends, disclosed separately
options.C: Liabilities for future obligations

questions.explanation: Appropriations restrict retained earnings to communicate that certain amounts are not available for dividends. They don't represent cash or actual obligations.
questions.tip: Appropriations = RE restriction; informational only.

questions.question: Preferred stock (1,000 shares, $50 par, $80,000 total including APIC) converts to 4,000 shares of $5 par common. What is credited to APIC-Common?
questions.explanation: Common Stock = 4,000 × $5 = $20,000. Total equity from preferred = $80,000. APIC-Common = $80,000 - $20,000 = $60,000. No gain or loss.
questions.tip: Preferred conversion: use book value method; allocate excess to APIC.

questions.question: When stock rights are issued to existing shareholders:

options.A: A journal entry is required to record the rights at fair value
options.B: Only a memo entry is made; no journal entry until exercised
options.C: Retained earnings is reduced

questions.explanation: Issuance of stock rights to existing shareholders requires only a memo entry. When exercised, common stock and APIC are credited for the exercise price received.
questions.tip: Stock rights to shareholders: memo only until exercised.

questions.question: A company issues 5,000 shares of $10 par stock for $18 per share. What is credited to APIC?
questions.explanation: APIC = (Issue price - Par) × Shares = ($18 - $10) × 5,000 = $40,000.
questions.tip: APIC = excess over par × shares issued.

questions.question: No-par stock with a stated value of $8 is issued for $15 per share (2,000 shares). What is credited to common stock?
questions.explanation: Common Stock (at stated value) = 2,000 × $8 = $16,000. Excess of $14,000 goes to APIC.
questions.tip: Stated value functions like par value for no-par stock.

questions.question: Common stock subscribed is classified as:

options.A: A liability until shares are issued
options.B: Stockholders' equity when subscribed
options.C: Revenue when subscribed
options.D: An asset until payment is received

questions.explanation: Common Stock Subscribed is an equity account. Stock Subscriptions Receivable is either shown as a contra-equity or asset. When fully paid, shares are issued.
questions.tip: Stock subscribed = equity (like common stock).

questions.question: Translation adjustments from consolidating a foreign subsidiary whose functional currency is the foreign currency are reported in:

options.A: Net income as a foreign exchange gain or loss
options.B: Other comprehensive income
options.C: Retained earnings

questions.explanation: When the subsidiary's functional currency is the foreign currency (and different from reporting currency), translation adjustments go to OCI as cumulative translation adjustment (CTA).
questions.tip: Translation adjustment = OCI (CTA).

questions.question: The effective portion of gains on a cash flow hedge is reported in:

options.B: OCI, then reclassified to net income when the hedged transaction affects earnings
options.C: APIC

questions.explanation: Effective cash flow hedge gains/losses are initially recorded in OCI, then reclassified to earnings when the hedged forecasted transaction affects net income.
questions.tip: Cash flow hedge: OCI until hedged item hits P&L.

questions.question: In a quasi-reorganization, a company with a retained earnings deficit:

options.B: Eliminates the deficit by reducing APIC (with shareholder approval), creating a 'fresh start'
options.C: Issues new stock to cover the deficit
options.D: Cannot take any action; deficit remains

questions.explanation: A quasi-reorganization allows a company to eliminate its RE deficit by transferring amounts from APIC (reducing it) to eliminate the deficit. Assets may also be written down to FV.
questions.tip: Quasi-reorganization: fresh start by eliminating deficit with APIC.

questions.question: An investor owns 40% of an investee. The investee reports $50,000 in OCI (unrealized AFS gains). What does the investor record?

options.B: $20,000 investment increase and OCI
options.C: $20,000 investment income in net income
options.D: No entry; investee OCI is ignored

questions.explanation: The investor records its share of investee OCI: 40% × $50,000 = $20,000. Dr. Investment, Cr. OCI.
questions.tip: Equity method: pick up share of investee OCI too.

questions.question: Treasury stock:

options.A: Is included in shares outstanding for EPS
options.B: Reduces shares outstanding but is still issued
options.C: Is an asset of the company

questions.explanation: Treasury stock is issued stock that has been repurchased. It is not outstanding and is not used in EPS calculations. It can be resold or retired.
questions.tip: Treasury = issued but not outstanding.

questions.question: Treasury stock (cost $40/share, 1,000 shares) is retired. Original issue: $5 par, $12 APIC per share. What is debited to APIC?
questions.explanation: Entry: Dr. Common Stock $5,000 (1,000 × $5 par), Dr. APIC $12,000 (1,000 × $12 original APIC), Dr. Retained Earnings $23,000 (excess of cost over original issue amounts), Cr. Treasury Stock $40,000. The APIC debit equals the original APIC per share times shares retired = $12,000.
questions.tip: Retirement: debit par, original APIC, and excess to RE. APIC debit = original APIC balance.

questions.question: OCI items should be presented:

options.B: Net of tax, or gross with aggregate tax shown separately
options.C: Only on an after-tax basis

questions.explanation: OCI can be presented either net of tax for each item or gross with a single line item for aggregate income tax effect.
questions.tip: OCI: net of tax or gross with aggregate tax effect.

questions.question: Warrants (originally credited to APIC-Warrants for $5,000) are exercised for 500 shares of $10 par at $25 exercise price. What is credited to APIC-Common?
questions.explanation: Entry: Dr. Cash $12,500 (500 × $25), Dr. APIC-Warrants $5,000, Cr. Common Stock $5,000 (500 × $10 par), Cr. APIC-Common $12,500 (balancing). The $5,000 APIC-Warrants is transferred to equity, plus $7,500 excess cash over par, totaling $12,500 credited to APIC-Common.
questions.tip: Warrant exercise: APIC-Common = cash excess over par + warrant value transferred.

questions.question: When shareholders donate their shares back to the company:

options.A: The shares are recorded as treasury stock at fair value
options.B: A memo entry is made; shares can be resold
options.C: Revenue is recognized equal to fair value

questions.explanation: Donated treasury shares are recorded at zero cost (memo entry). When resold, the entire proceeds are credited to APIC-Donated Capital or APIC-Treasury Stock.
questions.tip: Donated treasury stock: no cost basis; sales go to APIC.

questions.question: Under the par value method for treasury stock, shares are recorded at:

options.B: Par value, with the difference charged to APIC and/or retained earnings
options.C: Cost

questions.explanation: Par value method records treasury stock at par value. The difference between cost and par is first charged to APIC (from original issue) and any excess to retained earnings.
questions.tip: Par value method: treasury at par; excess reduces APIC then RE.

questions.question: Which is required in presenting OCI?

options.A: Showing only the net change in AOCI
options.B: Displaying each component of OCI, current period and cumulative
options.C: Combining all OCI items into a single line
options.D: Disclosing OCI only in the notes

questions.explanation: Each major component of OCI must be displayed, both current period amounts and cumulative balances (AOCI). A statement of changes in AOCI is also common.
questions.tip: OCI: show each component, current and cumulative.

questions.question: A scrip dividend is:

options.B: A promissory note to pay a dividend in the future
options.C: A dividend paid in property
options.D: A special dividend for preferred shareholders

questions.explanation: A scrip dividend is a note payable to shareholders promising to pay a cash dividend at a future date, often with interest. Dr. Retained Earnings, Cr. Notes Payable.
questions.tip: Scrip dividend = IOU for future cash dividend.

questions.question: A company declares a property dividend, distributing investments with a book value of $100,000 and fair value of $130,000. What is the effect on retained earnings?

options.B: Decrease of $130,000
options.C: Decrease of $30,000

questions.explanation: Property dividend: remeasure property to FV (recognize $30,000 gain in NI which increases RE). Then Dr. Retained Earnings $130,000, Cr. Investment $130,000. Net RE effect = -$130,000 + $30,000 = -$100,000 if combined, but the dividend itself reduces RE by $130,000.
questions.tip: Property dividend: first adjust to FV (gain/loss), then reduce RE by FV.

questions.question: A liquidating dividend represents:

options.B: A return of capital to shareholders, charged to APIC rather than retained earnings
options.C: A dividend paid only during bankruptcy

questions.explanation: A liquidating dividend is a return of invested capital to shareholders, not a distribution of earnings. It is debited to APIC (or other capital accounts) rather than retained earnings.
questions.tip: Liquidating dividend = return of capital from APIC.
